SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.jalapeno
Interface ObjectManager

public interface ObjectManager

API defintion for storing and operating with POJOs in database.

Field Summary

Field Detail

FETCH_POLICY_EAGER

static final int FETCH_POLICY_EAGER

Fetch Policy EAGER means that an instance of user defined POJO class is always returned and all properties are immediately assigned according to database values. If any of properties refer to other persistent objects such references are followed and corresponding objects are retrieved from the database.

Fetch Policy is EAGER can potentially lead to retrieving very big chunks of data from database and OutOfMemoryError.

See Also:
Settings.setFetchPolicy(int), Constant Field Values

FETCH_POLICY_LAZY

static final int FETCH_POLICY_LAZY

Fetch Policy LAZY means that an instance of a subclass extending user defined POJO class is returned. Its properties are only retrieved on first attempt to access the object.

Fetch Policy LAZY is not supported for access type FIELDS. However application can call ObjectManager method swizzle() to fetch such properties.

See Also:
Settings.setFetchPolicy(int), Constant Field Values

FETCH_POLICY_REFETCH_AFTER_SAVE

static final int FETCH_POLICY_REFETCH_AFTER_SAVE

Fetch policy FETCH_POLICY_REFETCH_AFTER_SAVE means that after any object is saved it is refetched from the database and any changes caused by database triggers, relationships or %OnSave() methods are reflected back in client context. This is the default behaviour. Obviously this value adds some additional overhead on performance.

See Also:
Settings.setFetchPolicy(int), Constant Field Values

FETCH_POLICY_DISCARD_AFTER_SAVE

static final int FETCH_POLICY_DISCARD_AFTER_SAVE

Fetch policy FETCH_POLICY_DISCARD_AFTER_SAVE means that after any object is saved it is discarded from client context. POJO values remain unchanged and any proxy objects are discarded. This behaviour improves performance but it can lead to an inconsistency between client and database data. For example inverse values for relationships are not set.

See Also:
Settings.setFetchPolicy(int), Constant Field Values

CLIENT_CACHE_WEAK

static final int CLIENT_CACHE_WEAK
See Also:
Constant Field Values

CLIENT_CACHE_STRONG

static final int CLIENT_CACHE_STRONG
See Also:
Constant Field Values

ACCESS_METHOD_GENERATE_HELPERS

static final int ACCESS_METHOD_GENERATE_HELPERS

Access Policy is ACCESS_METHOD_GENERATE_HELPERS means that ASM library must be in classpath of the application. It can be downloaded from http://asm.objectweb.org/download/index.html, choose asm-3.1.jar download. If the library is not found exception will be thrown.

See Also:
Settings.setAccessPolicy(int), Constant Field Values

ACCESS_METHOD_FLEXIBLE

static final int ACCESS_METHOD_FLEXIBLE

Access Policy ACCESS_METHOD_FLEXIBLE means that ASM library might be used if found. If it is not found in classpath a warning message will be printed to System.err and reflection will be used to access data.

See Also:
Settings.setAccessPolicy(int), Constant Field Values

ACCESS_METHOD_USE_REFLECTION

static final int ACCESS_METHOD_USE_REFLECTION

Access Policy ACCESS_METHOD_USE_REFLECTION means that access to POJO fields or properties is always done using reflection.

See Also:
Settings.setAccessPolicy(int), Constant Field Values
Method Detail

startTransaction

void startTransaction()
                      throws java.lang.Exception
Starts new transaction.

If ObjectManager is not inside a transaction then each save() (as well as insert() and and update()) starts its own transaction.

Transaction can also be controlled via underlying JDBC connection. This will probably be a preferred way in container environment when transactions are controlled by container.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If ObjectManager is not connected or already inside a transaction or an error occurred starting transaction.

commit

void commit()
            throws java.lang.Exception
Flushes JVM memory to the database and commits the transaction.

If application controls saving objects to the database it should call commit(false) for better performance to avoid unnecessary step of flushing.

If ObjectManager is not inside a transaction then each save() (as well as insert() and and update()) starts its own transaction.

Transaction can also be controlled via underlying JDBC connection. This will probably be a preferred way in container environment when transactions are controlled by container.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If ObjectManager is not connected or not inside a transaction or an error occurred committing the transaction.
See Also:
commit(boolean), flush()

commit

void commit(boolean flush)
            throws java.lang.Exception
Commits the transaction possibly flusing objects in persistent context in JVM memory to the database.

If ObjectManager is not inside a transaction then each save() (as well as insert() and and update()) starts its own transaction.

Transaction can also be controlled via underlying JDBC connection. This will probably be a preferred way in container environment when transactions are controlled by container.

Parameters:
flush - If true than calls flush() before comitting transaction.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If ObjectManager is not connected or not inside a transaction or an error occurred committing the transaction.
See Also:
flush(), commit()

rollback

void rollback()
              throws java.lang.Exception
Rolls back the transaction.

If ObjectManager is not inside a transaction then each save() (as well as insert() and and update()) starts its own transaction.

Transaction can also be controlled via underlying JDBC connection. This will probably be a preferred way in container environment when transactions are controlled by container.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If ObjectManager is not connected or not inside a transaction or an error occurred rolling back the transaction.

isInTransaction

boolean isInTransaction()
                        throws java.lang.Exception
Queries whether ObjectManager is inside transaction. This method returns true transactional state of the Objectmanager regardless how transactions are controlled, by calling methods of ObjectManager itself or inside JDBC Connection object.

If ObjectManager is not inside a transaction then each save() (as well as insert() and and update()) starts its own transaction.

Returns:
True if ObjectManager is inside transaction, false otherwise.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

Throws:
java.lang.Exception

openByPrimaryKey

java.lang.Object openByPrimaryKey(java.lang.Class clazz,
                                  java.lang.Object primaryKey)
                                  throws java.lang.Exception
Find an object with given key value in data store and instantiates it in JVM memory.

This method accepts key value in the following representations:

  • If a primary key is defined for class clazz then it can be a String consisting of comma separated values of properties that are included in primary key defintion. In case of single-property key it is just a value of the property.
  • If a composite primary key is defined for class clazz it also can be an array of primary key values rather than a coma-sperated string.
  • An opaque Key object as it is returned by getPrimaryKey() method.
  • A string produced by toString() method of an opaque Key object as it is returned by getPrimaryKey() method.

Parameters:
clazz -
primaryKey - String value of primary key or Key object as it was returned by getPrimaryKey() method.
Returns:
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If a problem occured opening the object or an object with a given key value does not exist.
See Also:
getPrimaryKey(Object)

openByQuery

java.util.Iterator openByQuery(java.lang.Class clazz,
                               java.lang.String sqlCondition,
                               java.lang.Object[] args)
                               throws java.lang.Exception
Opens all objects of given class that satisfy a given simple condition, specified in SQL syntax.

If the actual object belongs to a subclass of cacheClassName, it will be opened correctly. However, in the case when there are many such objects, performance can degrade significantly.

The condition supplied to this method only can be a simple one. That is, it may only refers to properties of a single object (single row in one SQL table). For example, for class Sample.Person valid conditions can be "Name %STARTSWITH ?", "Home_City = ?" or "ID BETWEEN ? AND ?". It can also include "ORDER BY" clause, suc as: "Home_City = ? ORDER BY Name". If a particular ordering was specified in SQL statement, the ordering is preserved by Iterator.

When a more complex condition is required, the method openByQuery(String,Object[]) should be used.

Parameters:
clazz - Class to which (or its subclasses) objects belong.
sqlCondition - A simple condition on objects, in SQL syntax. It can refer only to properties of a single object.
args - Parameters to replace "?" in condition. If there are no parameters, the condition may be null or an empty array.
Returns:
Iterator in the form of java.util.Iterator, that iterates over all opened objects in specified order.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
openByQuery(java.lang.String,java.lang.Object[])

openByQuery

java.util.Iterator openByQuery(java.lang.String sqlQuery,
                               java.lang.Object[] args)
                               throws java.lang.Exception
Opens all objects as POJOs (if POJO class is available) that satisfy a given SQL query. This is the same as the call to: openByQuery (sqlQuery, args, false); SQL statement must satisfy the following additional requirments:
  1. The first returned column should be a fully qualified %ID column for some table. For instance, when openeing Sample.Person objects, the first coulmn should be "Sample.Person.%ID".
  2. If particular ordering is required then columns in "ORDER BY" clause should be specified by names, not by numbers.

Example of valid SQL statement for the purpose of opening objects of class Sample.Employee is:

SELECT Sample.Employee.%ID, Sample.Employee.Name, Sample.Company.Name FROM Sample.Employee, Sample.Company WHERE Revenue > ? AND Company = Sample.Company.ID Order by Sample.Company.Name, Sample.Employee.Name

If actual objects belong to subclasses of the class specified by the first column of SQL statement, they will be opened correctly. However in case when there are many such objects performance can be significantly degraded.

Parameters:
sqlQuery - A valid SQL statement, satisfying additional requirments, described above.
args - Parameters to replace "?" in query. If there are no parameters, it may be null or an empty array.
Returns:
Iterator in the form of java.util.Iterator, that iterates over all opened objects in specified order.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

getId

java.io.Serializable getId(java.lang.Object pojo)
                           throws java.lang.Exception
This method returns Internal Database Id of the given object. If an object is attached then Id of correponding proxy is returned. For detached object Id value is returned if object class has a placeholder for internal Id, i.e. a property (possibly private) that is designated to be used to store internal Id.

If the object class does not provide for Id placeholder then null is returned for detached object. For instances of such classes to find out internal Id one must first attach object by calling attach(Object jalapeno) method.

Parameters:
pojo - An object Id of which is requested
Returns:
Internal Database Id of the given object. Usually represented as java.lang.String or, in some cases as java.lang.Integer
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
getPrimaryKey(Object), attach(Object)

getPrimaryKey

java.lang.Object getPrimaryKey(java.lang.Object pojo)
                               throws java.lang.Exception
This method returns Primary Key of the given object. The result may be an instance of some class that provides detailed information about this primary key.

Return value of this method is accepted as an argument to openByPrimaryKey() and removeFromDatabaseByPrimaryKey methods. String representation of the value obtained by calling toString() method is also accepted as an argument to those methods.

Parameters:
pojo - An object Primary Key for which is requested.
Returns:
Primary Key of the given object possibly represnted as instance of a special class.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
getId(Object), openByPrimaryKey(Class, Object), removeFromDatabaseByPrimaryKey(Class, Object)

insert

java.io.Serializable insert(java.lang.Object pojo,
                            boolean deep)
                            throws java.lang.Exception
Creates a new instance in a database corresponding to a given POJO.

Parameters:
pojo - Object to be saved in the database.
deep - If true than deep save is performed meaning that any objects to which the given object has references are also saved.
Returns:
Id of newly created database instance.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If an error occured while saving object. For instance if constraint violation is encountered such as an object with the same primary key already exists in database.
See Also:
save(Object, boolean), update(Object, boolean)

update

void update(java.lang.Object pojo,
            boolean deep)
            throws java.lang.Exception
Updates an instance in the database corresponding to a given POJO.

Parameters:
pojo - Object to be saved in the database.
deep - If true than deep save is performed meaning that any objects to which the given object has references are also saved.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If an error occured while saving object or if an instance corresponding to a given POJO is not found in the database.
See Also:
insert(Object, boolean), save(Object, boolean)

save

java.io.Serializable save(java.lang.Object pojo,
                          boolean deep)
                          throws java.lang.Exception
Creates a new instance in a database or updates existing one corresponding to a given POJO.

The object is considered to be existing if one of the following is true (conditions checked in a given order):

  • Given POJO is attached to existing database instance.
  • Given POJO class has a placeholder for internal Id and its value is not null.
  • Given POJO class does not have a placeholder for internal Id, POJO itself is not attached to any (new or existing) database instance and an instance with the same primary key as given POJO exists in the database.

Parameters:
pojo - Object to be saved in the database.
deep - If true than deep save is performed meaning that any objects to which the given object has references are also saved.
Returns:
Id of the database instance.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If an error occured while saving object.
See Also:
insert(Object, boolean), update(Object, boolean), getId(Object)

purgeFromMemory

void purgeFromMemory(java.lang.Object pojo)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
Remove the association between a given instance of POJO and any database proxies and closes correponding proxy object (if any). Close the corresponding object in server memory, if the connection uses Full Java Binding.

Parameters:
pojo - An object to be unassociated.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - if a problems are encoutered while attempting to close the associated proxy object. Note the exception is not thrown if a proxy object is simply not found.

attach

void attach(java.lang.Object pojo)
            throws java.lang.Exception
Attaches a POJO to a persistent context without saving it. If the POJO was previously attached (e.g. obtained one of the open() methods of the Object Manager, saved or attached and purged later, then it is reattached. The same happens if it was attached in one of an earlier sessions using another instance of ObjectManager. For an attached POJO, this method does nothing. For a new POJO, this method creates a proxy object for it.

All changes in the POJO are merged into the corresponding proxy object in this method call.

Parameters:
pojo - An object to be attached to persistent context.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

refresh

void refresh(java.lang.Object pojo)
             throws java.lang.Exception
Update the data inside a POJO to reflect any changes in the database.

Parameters:
pojo - Object to be updated
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

swizzle

void swizzle(java.lang.Object pojo)
             throws java.lang.Exception
Forces fetching data from the database for shadow objects used whith Fetch Policy LAZY

If supplied parameter is not a shadow object but a normal POJO this method does nothing.

After this method has completed it is guaranteed that all properties of this object can be accessed without a request to database and all persistent objects referred directly from the given object can be used without accessing database. In other words direct properties of the given object can be used after this method even if ObjectManager has disconnected from the database.

Parameters:
pojo - Object to swizzle data in.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
Settings.setFetchPolicy(int), detach(Object)

detach

java.lang.Object detach(java.lang.Object pojo)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
Ensures that all data in the given object and all objects reachable from it be following references can be accessed without connection to the database.

The object returned from this method is associated with the same persistent instance in the database but is guranteed to contain all data, be instance of a user defined data class (and not a subclass of it) and refer only to such objects.

NB: This method potentially can retrieve very big amount of data and cause OutOfMemoryError.

This method is only useful if Fetch Ploicy used is LAZY. If it is EAGER then all instances retruned by ObjectManager are detached objects.

Parameters:
pojo - Object to detach from ObjectManager
Returns:
An object that is an instance of a user defined POJO class. It may be the same object as a given parameter or a different one.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
Settings.setFetchPolicy(int), swizzle(Object)

flush

void flush()
           throws java.lang.Exception
Synchronize the persistence context with the underlying database. All objects known to persistent context are saved in the database. However transaction, if exist, is not committed so the change is not final.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception - if an error occurred while flashing, e.g. connection problem or constraint violation.

removeFromDatabase

void removeFromDatabase(java.lang.Object pojo)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
Removes an object from the underlying data store. Finds a coresponding persistent database object and deletes it.

Parameters:
pojo - An object that corresponds to the object to be deleted from database.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If delete failed or if corresponding database object is not found.

removeFromDatabase

void removeFromDatabase(java.lang.Class clazz,
                        java.lang.Object id)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
Removes an instance of given class with a given ID from the underlying data store.

Parameters:
clazz - Java class of the object.
id - Internal id value of the object to delete.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If delete failed or if corresponding database object is not found.

removeFromDatabaseByPrimaryKey

void removeFromDatabaseByPrimaryKey(java.lang.Class clazz,
                                    java.lang.Object key)
                                    throws java.lang.Exception
Removes an instance of given class with a given ID from the underlying data store.

This method accepts key value in the following representations:

  • If a primary key is defined for class clazz then it can be a String consisting of comma separated values of properties that are included in primary key defintion. In case of single-property key it is just a value of the property.
  • An opaque Key object as it is returned by getPrimaryKey() method.
  • A string produced by toString() method of an opaque Key object as it is returned by getPrimaryKey() method.

Parameters:
clazz - Java class of the object.
key - Primary key value or a Key object as it was returned by getPrimaryKey() method of the object to be deleted.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If delete failed or if corresponding database object is not found.
See Also:
getPrimaryKey(Object)

close

void close()
           throws java.lang.Exception
Closes ObjectManager and maked it unusable. All resources used by Object Manager are cleaned up.

If underlying JDBC connection was created by ObjectManager itself it is also closed. Correspondingly if ObjectManager was created on top of existing JDBC Connection underlying connection is kept untouched.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception

isOpen

boolean isOpen()
               throws java.lang.Exception
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

extentManager

ExtentManager extentManager()
Provides interface to manage database extent and perfrom such operations as kill extent, rebuild indices and populate extent with test data.

Returns:
an instance of ExtentManager

utilities

Utilities utilities()
Provides interface to perfrom some additional operations such as serialize objects to XML and deserialize them back.

Returns:
an instance of Utilities

purgeEverything

void purgeEverything()
                     throws java.lang.Exception
Removes all proxy objects from memeory.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception

settings

Settings settings()
Provides interface to configure settings for this instance of ObjectManager. Settings include Fetch Policy, Client Cache Type and ClassLoader.

Settings can be also configured on the application level for all ObjectManager instances.

Returns:
Instance of Settings
See Also:
ObjectManagerFactory.defaultSettings()

refresh

void refresh(java.lang.Object pojo,
             boolean deep)
             throws java.lang.Exception
Refrshes object in JVM memory with current database values

Parameters:
pojo - Object to refresh
deep - If true then follow references, i.e. refresh all objects reachable from this
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If refresh failed
